title: Is It Okay for Kids to Use Calculators for Math Homework?
description: When calculators help learning and when they hurt it – a practical guide for parents.

content.intro: "Why do I need to learn this? I have a calculator!" It's a fair question. When should kids use calculators, and when should they put them away?

sections.text: It depends on the goal of the assignment.

items: Building number sense and fluency? No calculator.
Learning a new concept or procedure? Usually no.
Applying concepts to complex problems? Maybe.
Real-world problem solving with messy numbers? Often yes.

rows: Verify answers after attempting by hand
Slower than mental math should be

sections.text: Kids who always use calculators often:

items: Can't estimate if an answer is reasonable
Have weak foundations for higher math

sections.text: A good rule: Can your child estimate the answer before using the calculator? If not, they should develop that skill first.

items: High school: More often (focus on concepts, not computation)

sections.text: Check the assignment instructions. Teachers often specify whether calculators are allowed. If unsure, ask. Most teachers appreciate parents who encourage computational fluency.

faq.question: My child's teacher allows calculators. Should I override that?
faq.answer: Respect teacher guidance, but you can encourage mental math at home. Ask your child to estimate first, or do some problems without calculator.

faq.question: What about phone calculators?
faq.answer: Same principles apply. But phones come with distractions. If calculator is needed, consider a dedicated calculator device.

faq.question: Won't calculators always be available in the real world?
faq.answer: Usually yes. But number sense – knowing if 15% of $80 is about $12 – protects against errors and scams. Mental estimation is a life skill.

cta.text: SoroKid builds the mental math skills that mean kids won't need calculators for basic operations.
